moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3: I decided to allow the Nimzo-Indian, something I've avoided until recently, preferring either the Bogo-Indian or the Queen's Indian, but I don't think my results against either of those openings has been great.
moves.4... O-O 5. Bd3 d5 6. Nge2 dxc4 7. Bxc4: Black adopts a solid formation, akin with the Slav and the Caro-Kann.  I hate having to deal with this...
moves.9. a3 Bd6: Black maintains an aggressive posture with this bishop.
moves.10. h3: Not so much to make a hole for the King at this stage as to prevent ...Ng4, attacking h2.
moves.10... b6: Black prepares a Queen's Indian style fianchetto.
moves.11. Qc2: This seemed a sensible posting for the Q, looking both at c6 and h7, and allowing Rd1 to support the d-pawn and point at the Bd6, Nd7 and Qd8
moves.11... Bb7 12. Bd3: Increasing the pressure on h7 but not threatening anything concrete yet.
moves.12... e5: If either c6 or d6 were to move, I'd have expected ...c5 first, so this came as a slight surprise.
moves.13. dxe5 Nxe5 14. Nd4: I decided to improve the position of this N rather than try to prevent Black swapping off the Bd3, since I didn't expect to be able to complete the attack with the Q and B on h7.
moves.14... Nxd3 15. Qxd3 c5 16. Nf5 Be5 17. Q: but I didn't want to swap Queens yet.  I already had designs on f7, though nothing concrete yet.
moves.17... Qc7 18. e4: I needed to block the lsb's diagonal and to free up my dsb at the same time.
moves.18... Rad8 19. Re1: Nimzowitschian over-protection of the e4 pawn.
moves.19... Rd7: Black prepars to double on the d-file, so White needs to complete his development quickly.
moves.20. Bg5: If Black completes his doubling, the Nf6 will be pinned.
moves.21. bxc3: If 21. Qxc3, N or B xe4.  Material is still even but White's pawn structure is ruined.
moves.21... Nxe4 22. Rxe4: ! White gets 2 minor pieces for the R+P
moves.22... Bxe4 23. Qxe4 Kh8: ?! not sure what this was in aid of
moves.24... Qc8: Perhaps this clears my last point.  25. Ne7 is not a fork with check.
moves.25. Ne7 Qa8 26. Qg4: I still didn't want to swap Queens and thought it would be useful to attack his Rd7.
moves.26... f6: ? If this was a deliberate exchange sac, I'll eat my hat.
moves.27. Qxd7 fxg5 28. Nf5: Threatens mate in one with Qxg7
moves.28... Rg8 29. Re7: Threatening 30. Nh6 gxh6 followed by Rxh7# or 30....R moves Rxg7 followed by Rah7#
moves.29... Qd8: This doesn't work but does allow a pretty finish.  I don't think Black could escape mate at this point.
